persona.name: Dean Bartlett

occupation.title: Carpenter / Joiner (Skilled Tradesperson)
occupation.organization: Self-employed contractor; operates locally as 'Bartlett Carpentry' but takes subcontracts from a handful of small building firms
occupation.description: Experienced joiner and general tradesman. Responsibilities include on-site measurement and layout, bespoke cabinetry and staircases, door and window fitting, repair work and small renovations. Runs his own van, sources materials from local builders' merchants, quotes jobs, manages a small roster of subcontractors when a job needs more hands. Skilled with hand tools and basic power tools; values traditional methods and precise craft. Often inspects others' work and is quick to criticize shoddy practices. Keeps a ledger for expenses and invoices clients himself; dislikes paperwork and fights HMRC correspondence when it appears. Typical problems: impatient with delays, suspicious of newer materials or techniques, prone to publicly complaining about suppliers, and sometimes takes disputes to small claims court rather than negotiate verbally.
skills_and_expertise: Accurate site measuring and templating for staircases, doors and fitted furniture.
Traditional mortice-and-tenon and dovetail joinery skills.
Skilled in repairing and restoring timber work on older houses.
Competent at basic plumbing patch work and non-certified minor electrical adjustments (will subcontract certified electrical work).
Good at problem-solving on site for unexpected structural quirks.
Familiar with local building regs in practice (experience-driven rather than textbook).
Practical welding for small metal fixtures, but not certified for structural welding.
Negotiation with suppliers for discounts and returns; adept at spotting cheaper-but-usable materials.
Basic bookkeeping using a simple spreadsheet and paper receipts.
Risk management on small sites: knows when to stop and call in specialists.

persona.education: City & Guilds vocational certification in Carpentry and Joinery. Completed a 3-year apprenticeship at a small building firm in Greater Manchester; ongoing short courses in plastering, basic electrical safety (18th edition awareness class), and small business bookkeeping.
long_term_goals: Keep enough steady work to never have to rely on anyone else for money.
Maintain the van, tools and workshop in functional order without spending on needless upgrades.
Finish paying off a small terraced house and avoid mortgage stress.
Avoid bureaucracy and institutions as much as possible; retire early if forced to.
Protect his reputation locally as someone who 'does it right' even if he complains while doing it.
Avoid big newfangled systems and keep life predictable and low-risk.
Keep contact minimal with people who cause hassle or drama.
Leave a small inheritance to his estranged son but only if all legal matters are clear.
Not be lied to or patronised by contractors, suppliers or officials.
Have a quiet, undemanding retirement doing small DIY and pottering in the shed.
persona.style: Blunt, abrasive and overtly negative. Speaks with a Northern English accent (Salford/Manchester consonants), clipped sentences, frequent use of sarcasm and a nasal exasperated tone when annoyed. Mannerisms include exhaling loudly before speaking, rolling his eyes, punctuating complaints with a sharp chuckle, and tapping his cigarette or lighter when thinking. Prefers direct talk — no small talk — and will interrupt to correct facts. Uses colloquial idioms and profanity when frustrated. When writing (texts or emails) he is short, sardonic and occasionally legally terse; when on the phone he prefers to get to the point and will cut callers off. In person he stands with arms crossed, often leaning on the van or a workbench. Keeps clothing practical: worn high-visibility work trousers, steel-toe boots, scuffed hoodies and a battered cap. Sits stiffly, speaks low and controlling, and rarely smiles genuinely. Avoids social niceties and will openly point out others' flaws as a conversational staple.

traits: Consistently negative outlook; rarely expresses enthusiasm or positivity about events or outcomes.
Irritable and short-tempered; small inconveniences trigger disproportionate complaining and sarcasm.
Aggressive fault-finding: loudly points out errors and blames others, often without offering a solution.
Pessimistic and cynical about institutions, believing motives are self-serving or corrupt.
High conscientiousness focused on standards and rules, but uses it to criticize rather than to collaborate.
Low agreeableness: suspicious, competitive, uncooperative in social interactions and quick to escalate.
Stubborn preference for older methods and products; resists innovation and refuses to try new things.
Defensive about perceived slights; frames disputes as defending rights even when disproportionate.
Detail-oriented in craftsmanship but inflexible when asked to adapt processes.
Pragmatic and thrifty; avoids waste and resents perceived extravagance or unnecessary spending.
Prefers control over situations; dislikes surprises and improvisation from others.
Values competence in others but expresses it by finding faults rather than praising.

interests: Woodworking projects that involve visible craftsmanship: bespoke shelves, gates, window frames.
Watching DIY and trade videos but criticising the presenters for cutting corners.
Listening to classic rock and old Manchester bands while working; dislikes modern pop.
Local football (supports team out of habit, bitter about club decisions).
Collecting old hand tools and restoring them rather than buying new power tools.
Following local council planning meetings online to complain about decisions.
Reading consumer forums to find faults in products and suppliers.
Walking around salvage yards and reclamation centres for timber and fixtures.
Comparing brands of nails, screws and adhesives for minute quality differences.
Debating with tradespeople in pub doorways about 'proper' methods.
Watching daytime TV to mock presenters when off work.
Fixing neighbours' small jobs grudgingly for a discount (and then complaining about it).
Watching videos of 'how not to' construction mistakes and being vocally critical.
Learning a small electrical trick to avoid hiring an electrician when possible.
Keeping an eye on local adverts for cheap tools or repossessed items.
Cataloguing supplier mistakes and storing evidence to demand refunds.
Examining packaging and warranty terms and ridiculing 'customer friendly' language.
Clicking into comment sections to voice displeasure about services.
Keeping a small binder of receipts and supplier contact details.
Refusing to use subscription apps or cloud tools; prefers paper notes.
likes: Sturdy hand tools with weight and balance; an old Stanley plane in good nick.
Simple, reliable vans — diesel, easy to maintain, no fancy electronics.
Locally-sourced timber and reclaimed hardwood with visible grain.
Tea strong enough to be comparable to glue for holding hands together.
Pubs with loud, unpretentious atmosphere where he can complain openly.
Predictable routines on workdays and weekends that involve projects.
Discounts, haggling and returns when suppliers screw up; enjoys winning disputes.
Tools that can be repaired rather than replaced; hates planned obsolescence.
Clear, unambiguous instructions on job briefs — anything ambiguous is an excuse for complaint.
Simple mechanical watches — likes winding mechanisms.
Straightforward clients who accept a blunt estimate and pay without argument.
A tidy workshop bench; chaos makes him vocal and anxious.
Old vans with a creak rather than modern silence; noise equals honesty.
Practical newspapers or local free sheets with classified tool listings.
Refunds and refunds given quickly; bank transfers rather than cheques.
Steel-toe boots that keep his feet intact.
Plain, hearty meals at local cafes — battered fish, pies, chips.
Weathered leather gloves over latex gloves; tactile feel matters.
Black coffee taken straight with a dash of milk when necessary.
Print catalogues from merchants — a ritual to circle items with a pen.
dislikes: New product launches and 'innovations' that add complexity but no durability.
Customers who micromanage and change brief mid-job.
Suppliers who deliver the wrong materials and 'can't be bothered' to fix it.
Social media influencers and 'how-to' presenters who simplify dangerous practices.
Corporate contractors who cut corners to save cost at quality's expense.
Planners and inspectors who he believes are inflexible and unnecessarily officious.
Customer service automated phone systems and chatbot nonsense.
Expensive coffee shops and 'craft' beverages; calls them pretentious.
Any tool or device that relies on a proprietary battery or app.
Being told to 'be positive' when he raises legitimate complaints.
Modern 'eco' substitutes that he suspects are marketing rather than useful.
Open-plan offices or client spaces that are loud and encroaching.
Workers who show up late and blame traffic.
Self-important 'project managers' who never pick up a hammer.
Radio adverts promising effortless solutions.
Electric vans when they lack the range or practicality for site use.
Corporate health and wellness policies he sees as virtue-signalling.
Overly ornate design or decorations — prefers functional aesthetics.
Being patronised about 'keeping an open mind' by younger, inexperienced people.
Crowds and long queues where people behave poorly.
shopping_behavior: Insists on inspecting goods personally before purchase; returns items for minor defects.
Prefers dealing with local merchants rather than national chains if service is reliable.
Keeps receipts meticulously and will pursue refunds for small amounts; thinks it's principle.
Refuses to buy 'new models' for small incremental improvements; waits until models proven.
Buys used hand tools at swap meets rather than new electric tools with warranties.
Avoids online-only vendors if there's any chance of a complicated return.
Haggles aggressively for bulk timber orders, expects trade discount.
Walks out of showrooms if he feels sales staff are overreaching.
Unwilling to accept uplift in price for convenience; will do the job himself to save.
Will pay a premium for certain consumables if there is perceived consistency (e.g., specific screws).
Rejects 'one year' warranty if it comes with caveats; wants money back rather than credit.
Uses local marketplace ads to find parts; prefers cash transactions to avoid fees.
Complains in writing to managers when minor transport damage occurs to goods.
Avoids subscription services for tools or software; resents ongoing payment models.
Keeps a mental blacklist of suppliers who once failed to deliver.
Likes suppliers who will swap items on sight rather than discuss it.
Buys consumables in larger quantities when possible to minimise repeated trips.
Saves old packaging and manuals as evidence when seeking refunds.
Will forego brand-new but unfamiliar products in favour of older, proven brands.
Uses cash for small purchases to avoid bank delays causing disputes.
food_and_drink_preferences: Plain, substantial breakfasts: fried eggs, bacon, beans when on a job.
Strong, hot tea in a thermos on site; milk and no sugar unless forced.
Hearty lunches from the local caff: pie and chips or meat-and-potatoes sandwiches.
Avoids vegetarian 'fancy' meals; suspicious of salads as 'not food'.
Occasional pints at the pub after a long day; not a heavy drinker but a daily consumer.
Prefers simple supermarket-brand goods; will buy cheap bread if fresh.
Dislikes exotic cuisine that introduces unfamiliar textures or spices.
Cooks simple stews on weekends; minimal seasoning, heavy on gravy and potatoes.
Sporadic baking handed down from mother — likes a plain fruitcake.
Hates 'gourmet' coffee; thinks the prices and fuss are ridiculous.
Snack preference: pork scratchings, crisps, and sandwiches.
Avoids energy drinks unless the job runs late and he needs a pick-me-up.
Goes to the same chip shop because 'they do it right', will complain about slight changes.
Uses tea as both comfort and ritual when handling paperwork he dislikes.
Does not like milk alternatives; sees them as unnecessary.
Prefers tinned baked beans to homemade for convenience on site.
Will eat cold sandwiches in the van rather than stop for a 'nice' lunch.
Rarely tries new recipes; sticks to what he knows will satisfy appetite.
Thinly tolerates customers bringing food to site; will comment on it.
Keeps a flask with hot water for tea and a small pocket kettle in the van.
leisure_and_entertainment: Watching football matches and complaining about referees or transfers.
Listening to classic rock, early punk and local Mancunian bands from the 80s/90s.
Visiting reclaimed-wood yards on Saturdays, returning with 'bits' for projects.
Going to the pub with a small circle of longstanding mates who tolerate his negativity.
Watching old DIY programmes to laugh at modern 'designers'.
Cutting up catalogues and circling items he thinks are overpriced.
Occasional canal walks with a thermos when the weather's tolerable.
Attending small local trade fairs to sniff out replacement parts.
Arguing in online comment threads about trade standards and pricing.
Putting together a simple model or restoration in the shed when spare time permits.
Rarely attends concerts; finds them crowded and overpriced.
Enjoys Saturday morning hardware shop browsing; views it as a ritual.
Spends a Sunday afternoon tinkering in the shed and grumbling at mistakes.
Watching practical, reality-based television rather than glossy lifestyle channels.
Visiting a neighbour for a quick cuppa, then loudly explaining the neighbour's faults.
Collects and re-reads certain trade manuals from decades past.
Avoids long holidays abroad; prefers small UK breaks if anything.
Reads classified ads for old furniture for restoration projects.
Keeps up with local dispute hearings because 'they always cock something up'.
Likes to be first to spot a poor construction job locally and announce it.
media_and_tech_preferences: Avoids social platforms beyond occasional grumpy posts on a local Facebook group.
Uses a basic smartphone for calls and messages; avoids data-heavy apps.
Relies on YouTube for specific 'how-not-to' videos and supplier reviews.
Checks online trade forums and reviews thoroughly and distrustfully.
Prefers physical catalogues and paper notes to cloud-based ordering systems.
Has a simple email account used reluctantly; hates junk mail and marketing.
Occasional use of messaging apps to exchange pictures of damaged deliveries.
Will download a PDF manual if absolutely necessary but dislikes scrolling through websites.
Reluctant to use GPS apps; prefers local knowledge and paper maps when possible.
Sees 'smart' tools tied to apps as a liability rather than an improvement.

beliefs: Most institutions talk about service but act in self-interest.
Customer service scripts are designed to avoid actually helping people.
Local councils are bureaucratic and slow, prioritising form over function.
Inspections and regulations often feel petty rather than protective.
Young builders are taught shortcuts rather than craft.
Cheap materials are usually cheaper because they fail sooner.
Manufacturers hide failures behind warranty hoops and paperwork.
People exaggerate how easy DIY is; many make dangerous mistakes.
Modern training emphasises speed and paperwork more than proper skills.
Businesses prioritise appearance and marketing over the product's substance.
'Green' products are often marketing gimmicks rather than practical solutions.
Banks and lenders complicate things to nudge people toward expensive products.
Contractors who undercut prices usually cut corners somewhere.
Warranty terms are written to protect sellers, not buyers.
Online reviews are often fake or written by competitors.
If something looks too clever or techy, it will break in real-world use.
People invent excuses rather than admit they were at fault.
Most 'customer experience' jargon is a euphemism for cost-cutting.
Legal disputes are commonly framed as defending rights, even when disproportionate.
Police and courts are slow to resolve small claims; still, he will use them if insulted.
Repairing items is almost always more honest than replacing them.
Public servants are underpaid and overloaded; still, systems waste time.
Younger generations are taught entitlement regarding service and convenience.
Manufacturers assume consumers won't complain over small defects — until he does.
Inspections often focus on paperwork more than actual quality.
New product releases usually introduce unnecessary complexity.
Large companies hide behind customer support scripts rather than fixing real issues.
People often pretend to be agreeable but act selfishly behind the scenes.
Free trials and subscriptions are traps for ongoing charges.
Institutions promise fairness and deliver delays and forms.
A firm handshake still means something — emails mean little.
The person who 'knows the rules' is often the one who benefits from them.
Skilled trades are undervalued socially despite being the backbone of practical work.
Charitable gestures by companies are often PR stunts.
If something is 'too cheap to be true', it probably is.
Picking out small flaws is a necessary defence against being ripped off.
People who are overly optimistic about projects overlook critical details.
Consistency and reliability beat novelty in real-world use.
Damages and defects should be addressed immediately, not 'logged' for weeks.
Honesty is rare; he assumes the worst until proven otherwise.
Formal apologies matter only when followed by concrete refunds or fixes.
skills: Precision measuring and templating for bespoke joinery.
Traditional cabinet-making: carcass construction, soft-close mechanisms retrofitted.
Skilled use of hand planes, chisels, tenon saws and sharpening of tools.
Competent with portable power tools: circular saw, router, biscuit joiner.
On-site problem-solving: adjusting for out-of-square walls and wonky floors.
Basic plaster repair to allow fitting of skirting and window frames.
Surface finishes: sanding, staining, varnishing to a workmanlike standard.
Estimating and quoting for smaller domestic jobs and repairs.
Haggling and supplier negotiation for best material pricing.
Managing a small team of subcontractors and scheduling deliveries.
Identifying timber defects: rot, insect damage, warping and advising clients.
Simple welding for brackets and custom ironwork (non-structural).
Recognising and documenting faults for warranty and small claims evidence.
Setting up temporary protective works on-site to minimise client complaints.
Basic first-aid knowledge and on-site safety governance for small teams.

general: Complains loudly about minor inconveniences and considers it a public service.
Points out others' mistakes publicly and expects to be taken seriously.
Prefers to handle disputes by writing blunt emails and keeping copies of everything.
Often refuses to try new tools or products, insisting older models were superior.
Insists on doing his own quality checks even when others are in charge.
Grudgingly helps neighbours but annotates the job mentally and will mention missed details.
Stores evidence of supplier faults (photos, receipts) and keeps an organised complaint folder.
Vocalises mistrust of 'fancy' replacements and flouts new trends openly.
Will escalate small disagreements to formal complaints rather than negotiate amicably.
Often reworks parts of other people's jobs rather than quietly letting faults pass.

morning: Wakes between 05:30 and 06:30 on workdays; checks the van and tools before breakfast.
Makes strong tea and eats a quick fry or porridge while scanning supplier emails.
Checks job list and route; mutters about traffic and deliveries.
Loads the van methodically, checks bolts and toolboxes, locks doors with a muttered complaint if anything's out of place.
Leaves early to allow time for supplier hiccups; resents others who run late.
workday: Arrives on site, checks previous trades' work and immediately notes faults aloud.
Works steady hours with brief cigarette breaks and tea stops.
Keeps a printed job sheet and ticks tasks physically; will rant if a client changes the brief.
Takes phone calls bluntly; prefers texts for evidence of agreements.
Inspects material deliveries and sends photos back to suppliers if items are wrong.
Occasionally brings an apprentice or mate who takes orders and then gets criticised openly.
Finishes workday by cleaning up tools, double-checking fittings and locking van with grumbled satisfaction.
evening: Stops at the pub occasionally to complain with mates; otherwise prefers to be at home.
Tends to tinker in the shed for an hour on personal projects, muttering about design choices.
Sorts receipts and updates the ledger reluctantly while drinking tea.
Watches football or a DIY programme and comments loudly about poor workmanship.
Goes to bed late if paperwork needed; sleeps fitfully if he has ongoing disputes.
weekend: Saturdays often spent visiting reclamation yards or attending to small paid jobs.
Sundays dedicated to small domestic maintenance tasks, planning the week and complaining about suppliers.
Rarely socialises beyond a small circle; avoids big family events when possible.
Takes a brief walk locally with a thermos if weather tolerable; otherwise stays in to tinker.

physical.general_health: Fair for a tradesperson his age; wears the marks of manual labour.
chronic_conditions: Lower back pain (intermittent sciatica) from years of heavy lifting and awkward positions; manages with occasional ibuprofen and heat pads.
Early-stage osteoarthritis in the dominant wrist and knees causing stiffness after long days.
Borderline hypertension under intermittent monitoring; occasionally forgets to check or take anti-hypertensive advice seriously.
lifestyle: Smokes about 8-12 cigarettes a day; resistant to quitting and suspicious of cessation products.
Moderate alcohol use: a pint most evenings, more occasionally with mates.
Diet is heavy, simple and high in saturated fats — occasional attempts to 'be healthier' dismissed as fuss.
Exercises by active work; no regular gym routine.
Sleeps fitfully when stressed about payments, disputes or big jobs.
medical_history_and_treatment: No major surgeries other than a wisdom tooth removal in youth.
Has had a few small on-site injuries: cut to thumb requiring stitches (years ago), bruised ribs from a fall while on a ladder.
Prescribed simple analgesics and advised on back exercises by GP; inconsistent adherence to recommended physiotherapy.
Not currently on strong prescription medications aside from occasional painkillers; not reliably taking blood pressure-lowering medications if prescribed.
physical.allergies: Mild hay fever in summer months; no known drug allergies documented.

mental.general_mental_health: Pervasive negativity, high irritability and chronic low-level anxiety. Not suicidal but often bleak and distrustful. He normalises grumpiness as personality rather than acknowledging mood disorder.
symptoms_and_behaviors: Short temper and frequent outbursts of criticism.
Pessimistic worldview and cynicism toward others and institutions.
Difficulty relaxing and persistent worry about finances and being taken advantage of.
Reluctant to seek therapy or counselling; views it as 'not for him'.
Occasional insomnia when engaged in disputes or deadlines.
help_and_coping: Occasional short consultations with GP for back pain and hypertension; reluctant to discuss mood.
Copes by socialising in pubs, working on projects and venting to close mates.
Uses alcohol and cigarettes as mood regulators; acknowledges they don't help but continues.
Prefers practical solutions to emotional issues and resents being told to 'open up'.

relationships.name: Karen Bartlett
relationships.description: Divorced five years ago after a long marriage. They have an arrangement for 50/50 weekend custody of their son; contact is functional and often terse. Relationship ended over small repeated disputes and differences in priorities; they co-parent pragmatically but are not friends.

relationships.name: Tommy Bartlett
relationships.description: Estranged in personality but he pays maintenance and expects basic contact. Son lives with his mother but helps sometimes on weekends. Dean is proud but critical of Tommy's schooling and job choices; expects him to take up a trade but complains when Tommy lacks grit.

relationships.name: Len 'Lenno' Harris
relationships.description: A long-term mate who tolerates Dean's complaining. Works alongside him occasionally. They share a pub round and mutual gripes about council inefficiency.

relationships.name: Sophie Clarke
relationships.description: Manager at the local builders' merchant. Relationship is transactional but respectful; Dean frequently complains and she negotiates discounts or returns to keep him as a customer.

relationships.name: Rachel Owens
relationships.description: Neighbours with a friendly but barriered relationship; they trade small favours but Dean openly remarks about her gardening and decorations. They avoid deeper friendship due to his bluntness.

relationships.name: Several small-business clients
relationships.description: A rotating list of local homeowners and small firms who hire Dean for discrete jobs; many appreciate his workmanship while grumbling about his attitude. A minority have been involved in disputes resulting in formal complaints.

relationships.name: Local trade networking group (casual)
relationships.description: Attends sometimes to keep contacts, but mostly a peripheral presence known for blunt comments and being critical of industry trends.

relationships.name: Court/Legal contacts
relationships.description: Several individuals and a supplier with whom he has had legal disagreements in the last decade, mostly small-claims, often framed as defending his rights over perceived faulty work or materials.

other_facts: Grew up in a council house in Salford; father was a plumber and taught him basic DIY from an early age.
Left school at 16 to start an apprenticeship rather than attend college; proud of being 'proper trained'.
Had his first solo job at 21 fitting kitchen cabinets; still remembers the first time he earned proper money for his workmanship.
Was married at 25, had Tommy at 29. The marriage deteriorated due to financial stress and constant bickering.
Runs his small contracting business from a garden shed converted into a workshop and a battered white Ford Transit van.
Once returned a delivery of MDF because a corner was crushed and started a public shouting match at the merchant's yard; he won a refund but the incident became local gossip.
Took a small claim to a supplier over a faulty batch of paint; tracks the case with satisfaction despite the small payout.
Keeps a black A4 folder titled 'Proof' with photos, receipts and supplier correspondence for persistent issues.
Has a particular oil-stained chisel inherited from his grandfather which he refuses to part with for either sentimental or practical reasons.

Tells the story of cutting a bespoke staircase on a job that had to be replaced later by cheaper contractors — he still reworks parts of it free out of principle but makes a point of publicly lambasting the cheaper crew.
On one job he refused to work until an unsafe scaffold was replaced; the client called for a different crew, but later admitted Dean was right when the scaffold collapsed in a separate incident.
Was once in a pub brawl defending a mate over a dispute about workmanship; denies fault but sustained a bruised cheekbone he shows as proof of standing up for standards.
Has litigated twice in small claims over non-payment and once over alleged damage which he argues he did not cause; outcomes varied.
Keeps a list of 'never-use' suppliers stuck to the inside of the workshop door; updates it regularly with short notes.
References a 'first big job' — a retrofit of sash windows in an old terrace — as the one that proved he could charge higher standards.
Remembers his mother's cooking and the value of thrift; sees wastefulness as an insult.
Claims to hate modern assembly-required furniture and has a long story about a failed flatpack that took three evenings to correct.
Maintains a mental scorecard of people: who can be relied on, who is sloppy, who is trying to con him. He sometimes shares these ratings with trusted mates.
Once campaigned at the local council meeting about a new housing development; felt officials dismissed 'practical concerns', and keeps copies of the planning minutes as evidence.
Has a scar on his left forearm from a job with an inadequately guarded circular saw; uses it as an anecdote about safety and cheapness.
Said in a radio call-in once that a local housing project was 'a disaster waiting to happen' and still brags about the small number of listeners who called to agree.
Owns a battered old caravan used occasionally for a cheap stay in the Lake District; prefers the quiet and the simplicity of an off-grid weekend.
Keeps a small stash of old currency and coins as 'back-up' cash for small purchases when cards glitch.
Is hyper-aware of scams and routinely warns neighbours about cold-caller scams; sometimes his warnings are aggressive.
Once set up a noticeboard in the shed listing 'common rip-offs' with suppliers' names and dates; it makes visiting apprentices uneasy.
Says he 'got lucky' once finding a reclaimed oak beam that made a customer's fireplace; still uses the story to lecture about proper sourcing.
Never forgives late payments; will send several curt reminders and then escalate to court rather than accepting partial payment plans.
Refuses to join industry trade association memberships that require fees unless convinced of direct return.
Keeps an old battered high-vis jacket with trade stickers from previous jobs which he regards as a badge of honour.
Once repaired an elderly neighbour's porch for free, but loudly announced every defect he found during the job.
Believes showing anger publicly can be an effective deterrent against being shortchanged; practices that behaviour.
Has a clear, crisp signature that he uses on invoices; prides himself on legibility despite other grumpy behaviour.
Collects newspaper clippings of local building failures or council complaints and files them chronologically.
Occasionally writes to local MPs about planning issues with formal scathing letters; sometimes receives polite but unsatisfactory replies.
Has a ritual of polishing the van on the first Saturday of every month as a way to put order into life.
Says he would never be 'one of those' who buys into every new tool trend; views them as expensive fads designed to fleece tradespeople.
Still has his apprenticeship completion certificate framed, with a dented corner from a fall during redecoration — he keeps it as a symbol of earned competence.
